MC.content: [artist as pervert?] art (particularly literature) can isolate performatively its own context for its own event > the “oeuvre”
MC.linkedContent: [artist as pervert?] art (particularly literature) can isolate performatively its own context for its own event > the “oeuvre”

SPOM.content: if commodity corrupts art [Derrida veering away from Marx], becoming-commodity attested to value it puts in danger > commodity put to work the principle of art
SPOM.linkedContent: if commodity corrupts art [Derrida veering away from Marx], becoming-commodity attested to value it puts in danger > commodity put to work the principle of art

MPM.content: art is a thing of the past
MPM.linkedContent: art is a thing of the past

MPM.content: de Man: “art leaves interiorization of past forever behind” > no dialectical passage from symbol to sign; art (like thought of thinking memory) linked to sign not symbol
MPM.linkedContent: de Man: “art leaves interiorization of past forever behind” > no dialectical passage from symbol to sign; art (like thought of thinking memory) linked to sign not symbol

MSUBJ.content: van Gogh did not paint ghosts, he reperspired nature, made it sweat, awful elementary pressures of commas [arrêt], scratches > now we see them too in the world
MSUBJ.linkedContent: van Gogh did not paint ghosts, he reperspired nature, made it sweat, awful elementary pressures of commas [arrêt], scratches > now we see them too in the world

MSUBJ.content: Artaud breaking down barrier in the other “arts,” abolishes border btwn all these “arts”
MSUBJ.linkedContent: Artaud breaking down barrier in the other “arts,” abolishes border btwn all these “arts”

A.content: great works, like Being and Time, neither science, philosophy nor poetics
A.linkedContent: great works, like Being and Time, neither science, philosophy nor poetics

PP.content: acc. king, sun, Thoth is a flimflam artist
PP.linkedContent: acc. king, sun, Thoth is a flimflam artist

TC.content: Artaud & Nietzsche want done w/ imitative concept of art
TC.linkedContent: Artaud & Nietzsche want done w/ imitative concept of art

DS.content: priority of art over nature still privileges order 1 then 2, the preference, the precedence (pré-séance) of the imitated
DS.linkedContent: priority of art over nature still privileges order 1 then 2, the preference, the precedence (pré-séance) of the imitated

DS.content: Bachelard: we love the graft, graft gives matter to flower, Art is grafted nature
DS.linkedContent: Bachelard: we love the graft, graft gives matter to flower, Art is grafted nature

DS.content: Jean-Pierre Richard: beauty of glorious lie is what art tries to render true, to do so, must put it under glass
DS.linkedContent: Jean-Pierre Richard: beauty of glorious lie is what art tries to render true, to do so, must put it under glass

P.content: for Hegel, art has a single meaning, une vérité une et nue, an etymon, that can be unveiled through history > wouldn’t this mean art is outside of history? but philosophers have always been too quick to deem art historical via opposition tekhnē/physis translated as art/nature
P.linkedContent: for Hegel, art has a single meaning, une vérité une et nue, an etymon, that can be unveiled through history > wouldn’t this mean art is outside of history? but philosophers have always been too quick to deem art historical via opposition tekhnē/physis translated as art/nature

P.content: oppositions structuring traditional concept of art: meaning/form, inside/outside, content/container, signifier/signified, represented/representer
P.linkedContent: oppositions structuring traditional concept of art: meaning/form, inside/outside, content/container, signifier/signified, represented/representer

P.content: asking what art means, the vouloir-dire of art, tautology w/out reserve, logocentrism of question “What is art?”—teleology & hierarchy prescribed in envelope of this question
P.linkedContent: asking what art means, the vouloir-dire of art, tautology w/out reserve, logocentrism of question “What is art?”—teleology & hierarchy prescribed in envelope of this question

P.content: both Heidegger & Hegel subordinate all art to speech, poem, the said, nomination
P.linkedContent: both Heidegger & Hegel subordinate all art to speech, poem, the said, nomination

P.content: for Hegel, telos of beauty is found in art not nature
P.linkedContent: for Hegel, telos of beauty is found in art not nature

P.content: art forms only one of the circles in the great circle of Geist, revenant (circle of art, circle of religion, circle of philosophy)
P.linkedContent: art forms only one of the circles in the great circle of Geist, revenant (circle of art, circle of religion, circle of philosophy)

P.content: when philosophy views itself as a work of art, it is represented on the model of one of its parts, so is philosophy then just a part of art? [living organism, biological metaphor]
P.linkedContent: when philosophy views itself as a work of art, it is represented on the model of one of its parts, so is philosophy then just a part of art? [living organism, biological metaphor]

P.content: if Hegel must begin w/ vulgar representation of art, the circle of circles allows him to start anywhere > “no absolute beginning in science”
P.linkedContent: if Hegel must begin w/ vulgar representation of art, the circle of circles allows him to start anywhere > “no absolute beginning in science”

P.content: for Hegel, art as 3rd term gives reciprocity to artist & artwork, art is thus 1st term
P.linkedContent: for Hegel, art as 3rd term gives reciprocity to artist & artwork, art is thus 1st term

P.content: in Hegel & Heidegger, an “it is necessary (il faut)” re: hermeneutic circle of art > must start w/ work of art, but how can you recognize it as art if you don’t already know what art is?: not a vicious circle, but an engagement of thought, circular feast, experience of limit, closure, resistance, humility > pas de cercle: le désir par cette répétition fidèle du cercle, d’accéder à l’encore infranchi, le désir d’un nouveau pas > lien sans liens, franchir le cercle sans s’affranchir de sa loi, pas sans pas
P.linkedContent: in Hegel & Heidegger, an “it is necessary (il faut)” re: hermeneutic circle of art > must start w/ work of art, but how can you recognize it as art if you don’t already know what art is?: not a vicious circle, but an engagement of thought, circular feast, experience of limit, closure, resistance, humility > pas de cercle: le désir par cette répétition fidèle du cercle, d’accéder à l’encore infranchi, le désir d’un nouveau pas > lien sans liens, franchir le cercle sans s’affranchir de sa loi, pas sans pas

P.content: third party (ein Drittes) regulates encirclement, art can play this role, a medium, can touch both edges > ambiguity of participation can’t exhaust it [what if this 3rd doesn’t rèleve?]
P.linkedContent: third party (ein Drittes) regulates encirclement, art can play this role, a medium, can touch both edges > ambiguity of participation can’t exhaust it [what if this 3rd doesn’t rèleve?]

P.content: art: domesticated in this history of truth, onto-encyclopedic economy, the machinery of the pose (Setzung/Entgegensetzung)
P.linkedContent: art: domesticated in this history of truth, onto-encyclopedic economy, the machinery of the pose (Setzung/Entgegensetzung)

P.content: all theories of art (Plato, Heidegger, Hegel, Husserl), you have to know what you’re talking about—can’t just say, via Rousseau, “I find the palace capitalistic,” this is extrinsic [Derrida makes a pretty good joke!]
P.linkedContent: all theories of art (Plato, Heidegger, Hegel, Husserl), you have to know what you’re talking about—can’t just say, via Rousseau, “I find the palace capitalistic,” this is extrinsic [Derrida makes a pretty good joke!]

P.content: Kant’s “conceptual scheme” for any theory of art: rational/formal/logical vs. irrational/matter/illogical > thing as formed matter
P.linkedContent: Kant’s “conceptual scheme” for any theory of art: rational/formal/logical vs. irrational/matter/illogical > thing as formed matter

P.content: hierarchy of art constituted on the analogical model of human language
P.linkedContent: hierarchy of art constituted on the analogical model of human language

P.content: Kant’s 3 fine arts: talking (words), figurative (gestures), play of sensations (tones) > a humanism
P.linkedContent: Kant’s 3 fine arts: talking (words), figurative (gestures), play of sensations (tones) > a humanism

P.content: Kant’s hierarchical classification of fine arts, a humanism regulated by language & body of man, language dominated by speech & gaze
P.linkedContent: Kant’s hierarchical classification of fine arts, a humanism regulated by language & body of man, language dominated by speech & gaze

PS.content: Artaud howls under headings: existence, flesh, life, theater, cruelty > promising an art prior to madness & work
PS.linkedContent: Artaud howls under headings: existence, flesh, life, theater, cruelty > promising an art prior to madness & work

FS.content: for Kant, [productive] imagination was already art itself > originally, did not distinguish btwn beauty & truth
FS.linkedContent: for Kant, [productive] imagination was already art itself > originally, did not distinguish btwn beauty & truth

SW.content: [re: Exodus 26:31] there are 2 veils/curtains btwn [holy/sanctuary] tabernacle & [holy/sanctuary] tabernacle of tabernacles [of holies/of sanctuaries] > 1st embroidered by artist, 2nd merely the work of a carpenter
SW.linkedContent: [re: Exodus 26:31] there are 2 veils/curtains btwn [holy/sanctuary] tabernacle & [holy/sanctuary] tabernacle of tabernacles [of holies/of sanctuaries] > 1st embroidered by artist, 2nd merely the work of a carpenter

DPi.content: for Schopenhauer, aesthetics not a disinterest but an anesthetic
DPi.linkedContent: for Schopenhauer, aesthetics not a disinterest but an anesthetic

REST.content: Derrida insists on strong necessity of Heidegger’s questions on art in spite of traditionality & symptomatic qualities
REST.linkedContent: Derrida insists on strong necessity of Heidegger’s questions on art in spite of traditionality & symptomatic qualities

REST.content: Van Gogh’s shoes are out of work in the (art) work, in the invisible ether of being painted
REST.linkedContent: Van Gogh’s shoes are out of work in the (art) work, in the invisible ether of being painted

REST.content: in Heidegger’s Origin both product and work of art produced (hervorgebracht) by hand of man, art resembles thing in its self-sufficient presence, product is more than half thing, less than half work of art
REST.linkedContent: in Heidegger’s Origin both product and work of art produced (hervorgebracht) by hand of man, art resembles thing in its self-sufficient presence, product is more than half thing, less than half work of art

REST.content: work like shoe-picture exhibits what something lacks in order to be a work, exhibits—in shoes—its lack of itself
REST.linkedContent: work like shoe-picture exhibits what something lacks in order to be a work, exhibits—in shoes—its lack of itself

REST.content: Heidegger’s step backward from truth of adequation to truth of unveiling can leave one disarmed in face of precritical, dogmatic, in face of “preinvestment” (fantasmatic, ideological)
REST.linkedContent: Heidegger’s step backward from truth of adequation to truth of unveiling can leave one disarmed in face of precritical, dogmatic, in face of “preinvestment” (fantasmatic, ideological)

REST.content: Origin is not about the metaphysical power of art, that’s what’s put in question
REST.linkedContent: Origin is not about the metaphysical power of art, that’s what’s put in question

IW.content: music as highest, most ideal art, its structure is pure breath, spiritus and psyche
IW.linkedContent: music as highest, most ideal art, its structure is pure breath, spiritus and psyche

PIO.content: Kant: imagination, site of genius, it’s creative (schöpferisch)—still, academic rules must be followed if Kunstler wants work to fit Idea underlying it
PIO.linkedContent: Kant: imagination, site of genius, it’s creative (schöpferisch)—still, academic rules must be followed if Kunstler wants work to fit Idea underlying it

+R.content: Benjamin’s deconstruction of the aura (authenticity) of work of art
+R.linkedContent: Benjamin’s deconstruction of the aura (authenticity) of work of art

+R.content: Benjamin: secularization causes indeterminacy of “once only (Einmaligkeit),” once-only of phenomena replaced by once-only of artistic operation (never w/out remainder)
+R.linkedContent: Benjamin: secularization causes indeterminacy of “once only (Einmaligkeit),” once-only of phenomena replaced by once-only of artistic operation (never w/out remainder)

+R.content: Benjamin theorizes that portrait of face is last “ritual religious art” before “technical reproducibility” > disappearance of the subject as art of the cenotaph [?]
+R.linkedContent: Benjamin theorizes that portrait of face is last “ritual religious art” before “technical reproducibility” > disappearance of the subject as art of the cenotaph [?]

C.content: contingent can do w/out discourse, a masterpiece can’t do w/out a cartouche (on the market & in itself: if you insist on this distinction) > even when the cartouche remains, is defunct: pas de cartouche, plus de cartouche > what will have been able to do w/out it? never touched, aussi impassible et invulnérable qu’aux harcèlements du trait: c’est peut-être qu’il était déjà dans la tombe, le cartouche
C.linkedContent: contingent can do w/out discourse, a masterpiece can’t do w/out a cartouche (on the market & in itself: if you insist on this distinction) > even when the cartouche remains, is defunct: pas de cartouche, plus de cartouche > what will have been able to do w/out it? never touched, aussi impassible et invulnérable qu’aux harcèlements du trait: c’est peut-être qu’il était déjà dans la tombe, le cartouche

C.content: why Derrida won’t waste his time describing Titus-Carmel’s artwork
C.linkedContent: why Derrida won’t waste his time describing Titus-Carmel’s artwork

C.content: how can we delimit all the features (traits) [of artwork] when the absent one haunts, obsesses, besieges (assiège) [plus qu’un autre] > avec égale sans (trait d’union: with-out [in English])
C.linkedContent: how can we delimit all the features (traits) [of artwork] when the absent one haunts, obsesses, besieges (assiège) [plus qu’un autre] > avec égale sans (trait d’union: with-out [in English])

E.content: for Kant, nature speaks to us through its beautiful forms, one can read the “ciphered language (Chiffreschrift),” nature’s signature as art productions
E.linkedContent: for Kant, nature speaks to us through its beautiful forms, one can read the “ciphered language (Chiffreschrift),” nature’s signature as art productions

E.content: even if this stance is opposed to Hegel [only art is beautiful], analogy btwn art and nature always provides a principle of reconciliation
E.linkedContent: even if this stance is opposed to Hegel [only art is beautiful], analogy btwn art and nature always provides a principle of reconciliation

E.content: for Kant, art is production of freedom by means of freedom
E.linkedContent: for Kant, art is production of freedom by means of freedom

E.content: for Kant, art is a power, aptitude, property, destiny of man (Geschicklichkeit des Menschen), and is distinguished from science (where to know is to know how to do, to be able to)
E.linkedContent: for Kant, art is a power, aptitude, property, destiny of man (Geschicklichkeit des Menschen), and is distinguished from science (where to know is to know how to do, to be able to)

E.content: for Kant, difference btwn free, liberal art and mercenary art is the difference btwn play/work
E.linkedContent: for Kant, difference btwn free, liberal art and mercenary art is the difference btwn play/work

E.content: [acc. Kant] free, liberal art: 1) play, not salaried work, free man (artist) is not homo oeconomicus, is more human 2) free, liberal art can utilize mercenary art w/out being contaminated by it 3) a productive, spontaneous, not reproductive (mimetic) imagination
E.linkedContent: [acc. Kant] free, liberal art: 1) play, not salaried work, free man (artist) is not homo oeconomicus, is more human 2) free, liberal art can utilize mercenary art w/out being contaminated by it 3) a productive, spontaneous, not reproductive (mimetic) imagination

E.content: genius of poetry, the highest of Fine-Arts: full expression of productive imagination receives its rules from Nature, thus breaking from mimesis > free unfolding-refolding of physis
E.linkedContent: genius of poetry, the highest of Fine-Arts: full expression of productive imagination receives its rules from Nature, thus breaking from mimesis > free unfolding-refolding of physis

E.content: liberal, free art relates to mercenary art as mind to body; free art enjoys itself but still incurs the unenjoyable incursions, lexical rules etc., of mercenary art; art still requires pedagogy
E.linkedContent: liberal, free art relates to mercenary art as mind to body; free art enjoys itself but still incurs the unenjoyable incursions, lexical rules etc., of mercenary art; art still requires pedagogy

E.content: why call them Fine-Arts (Beaux-Arts)? why not just call the product beautiful: because the product must still be implicated by its signature, beauty is ascribed to the passage btwn production/product; Fine-Arts: always of the frame & signature
E.linkedContent: why call them Fine-Arts (Beaux-Arts)? why not just call the product beautiful: because the product must still be implicated by its signature, beauty is ascribed to the passage btwn production/product; Fine-Arts: always of the frame & signature

E.content: Kant distinguishes agreeable arts from Fine-Arts, the former aims at enjoyment (jouissance, Genuss), the latter dispenses w/ concept (ohne Zweck) and enjoyment, but seeks pleasure (Lust)
E.linkedContent: Kant distinguishes agreeable arts from Fine-Arts, the former aims at enjoyment (jouissance, Genuss), the latter dispenses w/ concept (ohne Zweck) and enjoyment, but seeks pleasure (Lust)

E.content: Hegel critiques Kant’s 3rd Critique for staying at the level of “you must” > he very well evinces the moral order that sustains the aesthetic one
E.linkedContent: Hegel critiques Kant’s 3rd Critique for staying at the level of “you must” > he very well evinces the moral order that sustains the aesthetic one

E.content: though sublimity works against our senses, the sacrifice (Aufopferung) of the sublime keeps a power in view, sublime can dawn in art: attains a power greater than what was sacrificed
E.linkedContent: though sublimity works against our senses, the sacrifice (Aufopferung) of the sublime keeps a power in view, sublime can dawn in art: attains a power greater than what was sacrificed

E.content: economic calculation allows sublime to be swallowed
E.linkedContent: economic calculation allows sublime to be swallowed

LG.content: can one identify a work of art if it doesn’t bear the mark of a genre?
LG.linkedContent: can one identify a work of art if it doesn’t bear the mark of a genre?

BSi.content: Celan: the artist turns nature to stone, “be a Medusa’s head” (monkey, automata, art)
BSi.linkedContent: Celan: the artist turns nature to stone, “be a Medusa’s head” (monkey, automata, art)

BSi.content: poetic signature: not essence but where poem is coming/going: frees itself, by art, from art
BSi.linkedContent: poetic signature: not essence but where poem is coming/going: frees itself, by art, from art

BSi.content: [via Celan via Büchner’s Danton’s Death] art as species of marionette > marionette: an allegorical personification of technē, technical who and what
BSi.linkedContent: [via Celan via Büchner’s Danton’s Death] art as species of marionette > marionette: an allegorical personification of technē, technical who and what

BSi.content: via Celan, art as unheimlich, containing the inhuman: Medusa, monkey, automata, marionette
BSi.linkedContent: via Celan, art as unheimlich, containing the inhuman: Medusa, monkey, automata, marionette

OG.content: [vis-à-vis Rousseau] transgressing space, mastering exteriority (the inanimate), arts of space carry death w/in themselves—painting, often dead, carries you to depth of desert; voice, song, more alive [?]
OG.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Rousseau] transgressing space, mastering exteriority (the inanimate), arts of space carry death w/in themselves—painting, often dead, carries you to depth of desert; voice, song, more alive [?]

OG.content: w/ song, the living arts, outside imitates the inside, “paints” passions, is expressive; w/ inanimate arts, reproduction of the outside on the outside [painting?] > both externalize
OG.linkedContent: w/ song, the living arts, outside imitates the inside, “paints” passions, is expressive; w/ inanimate arts, reproduction of the outside on the outside [painting?] > both externalize

OG.content: for Rousseau, art and mimesis are disastrous (supplement) & emergence from inanimate, expression of passion
OG.linkedContent: for Rousseau, art and mimesis are disastrous (supplement) & emergence from inanimate, expression of passion

OG.content: for Rousseau, aesthetics passes through sign (semiology) not sensation, art is moral & ethnological [nonresponse to Western music can’t mean West Indians have different nerves!]
OG.linkedContent: for Rousseau, aesthetics passes through sign (semiology) not sensation, art is moral & ethnological [nonresponse to Western music can’t mean West Indians have different nerves!]

OG.content: for Rousseau, taste (cooking) has no moral element, no good aesthetics can come from it
OG.linkedContent: for Rousseau, taste (cooking) has no moral element, no good aesthetics can come from it

OG.content: [if art is moralism prior to sensation, by way of sign], attention to signifier degrades art by separating signifier’s effectiveness from the signified it signifies; supplement signifies nothing
OG.linkedContent: [if art is moralism prior to sensation, by way of sign], attention to signifier degrades art by separating signifier’s effectiveness from the signified it signifies; supplement signifies nothing

OG.content: trait permits imitation, donner lieu to art as mimesis, possibility of iteration, this life & death of art > technique & imitation: opens space of calculation (grammaticality, scientific intervals)
OG.linkedContent: trait permits imitation, donner lieu to art as mimesis, possibility of iteration, this life & death of art > technique & imitation: opens space of calculation (grammaticality, scientific intervals)

OG.content: trait is spacing itself, marks figures, works on surface of painting & time of music
OG.linkedContent: trait is spacing itself, marks figures, works on surface of painting & time of music

OG.content: for Rousseau, what never should have arrived, did [i.e. the supplement]; for Plato, for all onto-theology, meaning put out of play (le sens est mis hors jeu) in condemnation of art > Rousseau does not affirm (play/game of) writing but resigns himself to it
OG.linkedContent: for Rousseau, what never should have arrived, did [i.e. the supplement]; for Plato, for all onto-theology, meaning put out of play (le sens est mis hors jeu) in condemnation of art > Rousseau does not affirm (play/game of) writing but resigns himself to it

OG.content: society born by accident to repair the accidental catastrophe (Fall) [birth of supplement] of nature
OG.linkedContent: society born by accident to repair the accidental catastrophe (Fall) [birth of supplement] of nature

IF.content: [vis-à-vis Flaubert] as paradoxical as it sounds, Hegel frees passage for literature or writing called Art > having reached its end, one can discredit philosophy by treating it as art
IF.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Flaubert] as paradoxical as it sounds, Hegel frees passage for literature or writing called Art > having reached its end, one can discredit philosophy by treating it as art

IF.content: [Flaubert will not “divert the least thing” from Art] still philosophical to seek truth (idea) of idea as a primal scene of negativity/resentment in art, scene of guilt-ridden indebtedness to idea
IF.linkedContent: [Flaubert will not “divert the least thing” from Art] still philosophical to seek truth (idea) of idea as a primal scene of negativity/resentment in art, scene of guilt-ridden indebtedness to idea

UWC.content: “as if”: 1) imagination, utopia 2) Kant’s “as if (als ob)” from Critique of Judgment, points to finality of nature, is neither order of nature nor order of freedom [agent of deconstructive ferment] 3) oeuvres d’art, discursive idealities that define disciplines called Humanities, a subtle displacement of Kant’s idea: art is art not nature, it is free from all constraint/rules as if it were a product of nature
UWC.linkedContent: “as if”: 1) imagination, utopia 2) Kant’s “as if (als ob)” from Critique of Judgment, points to finality of nature, is neither order of nature nor order of freedom [agent of deconstructive ferment] 3) oeuvres d’art, discursive idealities that define disciplines called Humanities, a subtle displacement of Kant’s idea: art is art not nature, it is free from all constraint/rules as if it were a product of nature

EU.content: [vis-à-vis Kant] metaphysics as the teacher’s mistress (maîtresse du maître), as censor > for a teacher, a finite being, no lifting of censorship, only strategic calculation: censorship against censorship, debate of the best censorship [the idea of philosopher’s legislation found everywhere in man’s reason], censorship of reason: [Derrida asks vis-à-vis Schelling] is this strategy an art?
EU.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Kant] metaphysics as the teacher’s mistress (maîtresse du maître), as censor > for a teacher, a finite being, no lifting of censorship, only strategic calculation: censorship against censorship, debate of the best censorship [the idea of philosopher’s legislation found everywhere in man’s reason], censorship of reason: [Derrida asks vis-à-vis Schelling] is this strategy an art?

EU.content: acc. Schelling, every “new” philosophy makes a new “step (pas)” in form, poetic originality, a provocation/challenge to translation
EU.linkedContent: acc. Schelling, every “new” philosophy makes a new “step (pas)” in form, poetic originality, a provocation/challenge to translation

EU.content: Schelling’s originality: philosophy must possess formal originality (it’s a work of art)
EU.linkedContent: Schelling’s originality: philosophy must possess formal originality (it’s a work of art)

EU.content: Schelling: philosophy becomes truly objective only in art > an art of generalized translation
EU.linkedContent: Schelling: philosophy becomes truly objective only in art > an art of generalized translation

EU.content: Schelling: both poetry/philosophy require self-produced original image (Bild) of world
EU.linkedContent: Schelling: both poetry/philosophy require self-produced original image (Bild) of world

EU.content: [vis-à-vis Schelling] art can never be limited/programmed by State, there is no State culture > philosophy, which demands unconditional freedom, should reside in Faculty of Arts
EU.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Schelling] art can never be limited/programmed by State, there is no State culture > philosophy, which demands unconditional freedom, should reside in Faculty of Arts

EU.content: bureaucratic organization doesn’t provide for philosophy, has ceased being a free association in view of the arts (poetic translation)
EU.linkedContent: bureaucratic organization doesn’t provide for philosophy, has ceased being a free association in view of the arts (poetic translation)

SPEC.content: classically [?]: art preserves proper name, science forgets proper name > what then is psychoanalysis?
SPEC.linkedContent: classically [?]: art preserves proper name, science forgets proper name > what then is psychoanalysis?
